Asatruism

[TAB]Germanic neopaganism, also known as Heathenry, Ásatrú, Odinism, Forn Siðr, Wotanism, Theodism, and other names, is the contemporary revival of historical polytheistic Germanic paganism.[2] Dedicated to the ancient gods and goddesses of the North, the focus of Germanic neopagans varies considerably, from strictly historical polytheistic reconstructionism to syncretist (eclectic), Jungian, occult or mysticist approaches. Germanic neopagan organizations cover a wide spectrum of belief and ideals.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much of Germanic Neopaganism's origins are in 19th century romanticism, as the aboriginal cultures of Northern Europe came to be glorified. In the early 20th century, organised groups emerged in Germany and Austria. In the 1970s, new Germanic Neopagan organisations grew up in Europe and North America, although a broad division in the movement emerged between the folkish movement, who saw it as the indigenous religion of the Nordic peoples, and the universalist movement, who opposed strictly racialist interpretations. As present, established Germanic Pagan communities exist in Europe, North America, South America, and Australasia. A few adherents can even be found in South Africa.

[TAB]In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple.

Ces petits lieux de culte sont bien plus courants que les grands lieux de culte mais sont de taille plus réduite et sont bien moins richement ornés. Même le village le plus petit peut posséder un petit lieu de culte.

Anche il villaggio più piccolo ospita un tempio.

[TAB]In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete.

Seules les villes les plus prospères ont les moyens de construire de tels édifices. En effet, ils nécessitent d'énormes quantités de matériaux bruts et des artisans spécialisés doivent y consacrer des années de travail. Ainsi, il a fallu plus de deux siècles pour terminer la cathédrale Notre-Dame à Paris.

TEXT.English: Asatru Monastery

[TAB]A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un monastère est un édifice dans lequel les moines peuvent se retirer du monde et se concentrer sur le divin. Généralement, les règles de conduite y sont strictes afin de protéger ses membres, détachés du monde, de la tentation. Dans certains monastères, les moines sont totalement silencieux ; dans d'autres, les visiteurs ne sont pas autorisés à pénétrer dans leur enceinte. Les monastères ont généralement de nombreux rituels et services religieux quotidiens. [PARAGRAPH:1]A travers les siècles, les monastères ont souvent été des centres d'érudition. Dans les zones retirées, les moines étaient parfois les seules personnes sachant lire et écrire à des kilomètres à la ronde. Ils ont souvent servi de scribes, recopiant les textes sacrés de leur religion. Les monastères ont généralement de grandes bibliothèques possédant des textes religieux, scientifiques, médicaux et philosophiques.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Klöster sind Gebäude, in die sich Mönche zurückziehen, um sich auf Gott zu konzentrieren. In Klöstern gelten strenge Verhaltensregeln, die die Mönche vor Versuchungen bewahren sollen. In einigen Klöstern herrscht ein strenges Redeverbot, in anderen sind keine Besucher gestattet. Die Mönche selbst gehen täglich ihren religiösen Pflichten nach. [PARAGRAPH:1] In der Vergangenheit waren Klöster stets auch Zentren des Wissens. In abgelegenen Gegenden waren die Mönche oft die einzigen gebildeten Menschen, die als Schreiber ihre religiösen Schriften kopierten. Klöster haben nicht selten Bibliotheken, in denen unzählige religiöse, wissenschaftliche, medizinische und philosophische Texte aufbewahrt werden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il monastero è un edificio nel quale i monaci possono ritirarsi dal mondo e concentrarsi sul Divino. In genere, nel monastero vige un regolamento ferreo per proteggere i membri della comunità dalle tentazioni. In alcuni monasteri, i monaci erano completamente silenziosi e non erano permesse visite dall'esterno per non interrompere i rituali quotidiani e le cerimonie religiose. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nel corso dei secoli, i monasteri sono stati spesso centro di insegnamento: in alcune zone, i monaci erano sovente gli unici in grado di leggere e scrivere nel giro di diversi chilometri. Da sempre, i monaci sono stati utilizzati come scribi per copiare le parole sacre della propria religione; i monasteri ospitavano spesso delle biblioteche che contenevano testi religiosi, scientifici, medici e filosofici.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un monasterio es un edificio en el que los monjes pueden retirarse del mundo para concentrarse en los asuntos de la divinidad. En algunos monasterios, los monjes guardan un silencio total, mientras que en otros no se permite el acceso a los visitantes. Lo habitual es que sus miembros tengan que celebrar a diario muchos rituales y servicios religiosos. [PARAGRAPH:1] A lo largo de la historia, los monasterios han sido muchas veces centros de estudio. En las regiones remotas, los monjes podían ser las únicas personas letradas en muchos kilómetros a la redonda. A menudo han sido empleados como escribas, y se han dedicado a copiar los textos sagrados de su religión. Buddhist Wonder (Palace of Potala)

[TAB]The Potala Palace is located in Lhasa, Tibet Autonomous Region. It was named after Mount Potala, the abode of Chenresig or Avalokitesvara. The Potala Palace was the chief residence of the Dalai Lama until the 14th Dalai Lama fled to Dharamsala, India, after an invasion and failed uprising in 1959. Today the Potala Palace has been converted into a museum by the Chinese. [PARAGRAPH:2]The building measures 400 metres east-west and 350 metres north-south, with sloping stone walls averaging 3 m. thick, and 5 m. (more than 16 ft) thick at the base, and with copper poured into the foundations to help proof it against earthquakes. Thirteen stories of buildings – containing over 1,000 rooms, 10,000 shrines and about 200,000 statues – soar 117 metres (384 ft) on top of Marpo Ri, the "Red Hill", rising more than 300 m (about 1,000 ft) in total above the valley floor. Tradition has it that the three main hills of Lhasa represent the "Three Protectors of Tibet." Chokpori, just to the south of the Potala, is the soul-mountain (bla-ri) of Vajrapani, Pongwari that of Manjushri, and Marpori, the hill on which the Potala stands, represents Chenresig or Avalokiteshvara.[PARAGRAPH:2]The site was used as a meditation retreat by King Songtsen Gampo, who in 637 built the first palace there in order to greet his bride Princess Wen Cheng of the Tang Dynasty of China. Lozang Gyatso, the Great Fifth Dalai Lama, started the construction of the Potala Palace in 1645 after one of his spiritual advisers, Konchog Chophel (d. 1646), pointed out that the site was ideal as a seat of government, situated as it is between Drepung and Sera monasteries and the old city of Lhasa. The Dalai Lama and his government moved into the Potrang Karpo ('White Palace') in 1649. Construction lasted until 1694, some twelve years after his death. The Potala was used as a winter palace by the Dalai Lama from that time. The Potrang Marpo ('Red Palace') was added between 1690 and 1694.

Buddhist Wonder (Bezeklik Caves)

[TAB]The Bezeklik Thousand Buddha Caves are complex of Buddhist cave grottos dating from the 5th to the 9th centuries between the cities of Turpan and Shanshan (Loulan) at the north-east of the Taklamakan Desert, China. They are high on the cliffs of the west Mutou Valley under the Flaming Mountains. There are 77 rock-cut caves at the site. Most have rectangular spaces with rounded arch ceilings often divided into four sections, each with a mural of Buddha. The effect is of entire ceiling covers with hundreds of Buddha murals. Some ceilings are painted with a large Buddha surrounded by other figures, including Indians, Persians and Europeans. The quality of the murals vary with some being artistically naive while others are masterpieces of religious art.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Le Grotte buddhiste di Bezeklik sono un complesso di grotte rupestri buddiste che risalgono ad un periodo tra il 5° e il 9° secolo, situate tra le città di Turfan e Shanshan (Loulan) a nord-est del deserto di Taklamakan, in Cina. Si trovano sulle pareti occidentali della valle di Mutou, sotto le montagne Fiammeggianti. Ci sono 77 grotte scavate nella roccia nel sito. La maggior parte hanno spazi rettangolari con soffitti ad arco arrotondati spesso divisi in quattro sezioni, ognuna con un murale di Buddha; come risultato, ci sono soffitti ricoperti da centinaia di immagini di Buddha. Alcuni soffitti sono dipinti con un grande Buddha circondato da altre figure, tra cui indiani, persiani ed europei. La qualità dei dipinti varia, da alcuni artisticamente ingenui a veri e propri capolavori di arte religiosa.

TEXT.English: Buddhist Wonder (Nara's Giant Buddha}

[TAB]In 743, Emperor Shomu issued a law in which he stated that the people should become directly involved with the establishment of new Buddha temples throughout Japan. His personal belief was that such piety would inspire Buddha to protect his country from further disaster. Gyoki, with his pupils, traveled the provinces asking for donations. According to records kept by Todai-ji, more than 2,600,000 people in total helped construct the Great Buddha and its Hall. The 16 m high statue was built through eight castings over three years, the head and neck being cast together as a separate element. The making of the statue has started first in Shigaraki. After enduring multiple fires and earthquakes, the construction was eventually resumed in Nara in 745, and the Buddha was finally completed in 751. A year later, in 752, the eye-opening ceremony was held with an attendance of 10,000 people to celebrate the completion of the Buddha. The Indian priest Bodhisena performed the eye-opening for Emperor Shomu. The project nearly bankrupted Japan's economy, consuming most of the available bronze of the time.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Nel 743 l'imperatore Shomu emanò una legge in cui affermava che le persone dovevano essere direttamente coinvolte nella creazione di nuovi templi in onore di Buddha in tutto il Giappone. La sua convinzione personale era che tale pietà avrebbe spinto Buddha a proteggere il suo paese da ulteriori disastri. Gyoki, con i suoi allievi, viaggiò nelle province chiedendo donazioni. Secondo i registri tenuti da Todai-ji, più di 2.600.000 persone in totale contribuirono alla costruzione del Grande Buddha e della sua Sala. La statua, alta 16 metri, venne costruita per mezzo di otto getti in più di tre anni; la testa e il collo furono gettati insieme come elementi separati. La realizzazione della statua iniziò a Shigaraki. Dopo aver sopportato molteplici incendi e terremoti, la costruzione venne finalmente ripresa a Nara nel 745 e il Buddha è stato infine completato nel 751. Un anno dopo, nel 752, la cerimonia di inaugurazione si svolse con la partecipazione di 10.000 persone per festeggiare il completamento del Buddha. Il sacerdote indiano Bodhisena eseguì l'inaugurazione per l'imperatore Shomu. Il progetto portò quasi alla bancarotta l'economia del Giappone, consumando la maggior parte del bronzo a disposizione in quel periodo.

[TAB]The Crusades were a series of religion-driven military campaigns waged by much of Christian Europe against external and internal opponents. Crusades were fought mainly against Muslims, though campaigns were also directed against pagan Slavs, Jews, Russian and Greek Orthodox Christians, Mongols, Cathars, Hussites, Waldensians, Old Prussians and political enemies of the popes. Crusaders took vows and were granted an indulgence for past sins.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The Crusades originally had the goal of recapturing Jerusalem and the Holy Land from Muslim rule and were launched in response to a call from the Eastern Orthodox Byzantine Empire for help against the expansion of the Muslim Seljuk Turks into Anatolia. The term is also used to describe contemporaneous and subsequent campaigns conducted through to the 16th century in territories outside the Levant usually against pagans, heretics, and peoples under the ban of excommunication for a mixture of religious, economic, and political reasons. Rivalries among both Christian and Muslim powers led also to alliances between religious factions against their opponents, such as the Christian alliance with the Sultanate of Rum during the Fifth Crusade.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The Crusades had far-reaching political, economic, and social impacts, some of which have lasted into contemporary times. Because of internal conflicts among Christian kingdoms and political powers, some of the crusade expeditions were diverted from their original aim, such as the Fourth Crusade, which resulted in the sack of Christian Constantinople and the partition of the Byzantine Empire between Venice and the Crusaders. The Sixth Crusade was the first crusade to set sail without the official blessing of the Pope. The Seventh, Eighth and Ninth Crusades resulted in Mamluk and Hafsid victories, as the Ninth Crusade marked the end of the Crusades in the Middle East.

TEXT.English: Christian Wonder (Saint Mark's Basilica)

[TAB]Saint Mark's Basilica, the cathedral of Venice, is one of the best known examples of Byzantine architecture. It lies on St Mark's Square adjacent and connected to the Doge's Palace. Originally it was the "chapel" of the Venetian rulers, and not the city's cathedral. Since 1807 it has been the seat of the Patriarch of Venice, archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Venice. For its opulent design, gilded Byzantine mosaics, and its status as a symbol of Venetian wealth and power, from the 11th century on the building was known by the nickname Chiesa d'Oro (Church of gold).
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La Basilica di San Marco, la cattedrale di Venezia, è uno dei più noti esempi di architettura bizantina. Si trova sulla piazza adiacente e collegata al Palazzo Ducale di San Marco. In origine era la "cappella" dei governanti veneziani, e non la cattedrale della città. Dal 1807 è stata la sede del Patriarca di Venezia, arcivescovo dell'arcidiocesi cattolica di Venezia. Per il suo design opulento, i mosaici bizantini dorati e il suo status di simbolo di ricchezza e di potere veneziano, dall'11° secolo l'edificio è conosciuto con il soprannome di Chiesa d'Oro.

Dosan Seowon (alternatively, Tosansowon) was established in 1574 in what is present day Andong, South Korea, in memory of and four years after the death of Confucian scholar Yi Hwang by some of his disciples and other Confucian authorities. Yi Hwang had retired to the location in 1549 and begun construction on the facility, a private Confucian academy offering instruction in the classics and honouring the sages with regular memorial rites. Like other Confucian academies, Dosan Seowon serves two purposes: education and commemoration. The site was well known in Korea as one of the leading academies and was home to the Toegye School of Thought for over 400 years. Although the educational function of the facility has long since ceased, the commemorative ceremonies have been and are still held twice a year.
TEXT.French: Dosan Seowon (ou , Tosansowon) a été fondé en 1574 dans la ville nommé à présent Andong, et Corée de Sud, en mémoire, et quatre années après la mort de l'érudit Confucéen Yi Hwang par quelques-uns de ses disciples et les autorités Confucéennes. Yi Hwang s'est retiré à cet endroit en 1549 et a commencé à construire cette institution : une académie privée Confucéenne offrant l'instruction des doctrines et honorant les sages par des rites funéraires réguliers. Comme les autres académies Confucéennes, Dosan Seowon conserve les deux objectifs : l'éducation et la comémoration. Le Site était très connu en Corée comme une des meilleures académies, et a été le siège de l'Ecole de l'Esprit de Toegye pendant plus de 400 ans. Bien que la fonction d'éducattion de l'édifice a cessé depuis longtemps à présent, les cérémonies comémoratives sont encore célébrées deux fois par an..

[TAB]The San Kong is the collective name for the three major Confucian sites at Qufu. These consist of the Temple and Cemetery of Confucius and the Kong Family Mansion. The temple complex is amongst the largest in China covering an area of 16,000 square meters. The mainpart of the temple consists of 9 courtyards arranged on a central axis, which is oriented in the north-south direction and is 1.3 km in length. The first three courtyards have small gates and are planted with tall pine trees, they serve an introductory function. The first (southernmost) gate is named "Lingxing Gate" after a star in the Great Bear constellation, the name suggests that Confucius is a star from heaven. The buildings in the remaining courtyards form the heart of the complex. They are impressive structures with yellow roof-tiles (otherwise reserved for the emperor) and red-painted walls, they are surrounded by dark-green pine trees to create a color contrast with complementary colors.

Hellenistic

[TAB]The Hellenic religion, also referred to as Greek mythology, comprises an enormous body of stories about gods, goddesses, and heroes. These stories date back many centuries, preserved in pre-literate Greece through oral tradition. The Hellenic religion was polytheistic in nature, with innumerable local nature deities in addition to the major Olympian gods and goddesses. The Greek gods were human in form but possessed supernatural powers; they were born from other gods but never aged, they were immortal, could travel enormous distances instantly, speak through humans with or without their knowledge, etc. Some gods were the personified aspects of natural forces (for example, Helios was literally the god of the sun) while others had complex personalities and multiple functions associated with them (Apollo is probably the best example). [PARAGRAPH:1]The gods and goddesses were all related to one another as part of one large family, but there were clear generations of gods, and their interactions with each other were sometimes violent. For example, the Olympian gods had reached their place of dominance by casting out an earlier generation of gods and goddesses known as the Titans. This may be a mythical reflection of the struggle between the Greeks and the earlier culture that they displaced when arriving in the Peloponnesus around roughly 1000 BC. [PARAGRAPH:1]In addition to stories about gods, the Hellenic religion was also full of great sagas about the deeds of heroes, many of whom possessed a divine parent. Stories abound about figures such as Heracles, Perseus, Jason, and the characters of the Iliad. These humans frequently interacted with gods and even bested them at times. Many of the heroes were held in great esteem by the Greeks, especially "noble" characters such as Achilles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Although some of the well-educated Greeks had their doubts about the existence of the gods, the vast majority of Greeks did not question the validity of the stories. The Greeks used their religion to explain the doings of the natural world and their own origins; it was a source of pride to trace one's lineage or the founding of one's city to the actions of a god. [PARAGRAPH:1]Archaeology and linguistic analysis suggests that the Hellenic religion was heavily influenced by other religions. For example, the Greek Zeus, Roman Jupiter, Germanic Tyr, and Sanskrit Dyaus are all sky gods that share a common Indo-European origin sometime in the distant past. Other gods were borrowed or influenced from Near Eastern religions; Aphrodite possessed a very similar function to the Semitic goddesses Ishtar and Astarte. During the Hellenic period and afterwards, the Greek religion spread across much of the Mediterranean and Near East, influencing many of the previously existing religions and giving rise to new syncretistic mystery cults. Although the Hellenic religion is no longer followed, it continues to provide inspiration for artists throughout the world.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La religion hellénique, à laquelle on fait le plus souvent référence sous l'appellation de mythologie grecque, comprend un grand nombre de légendes sur les dieux, déesses et héros. Certaines de ces légendes remontent à plusieurs siècles, ayant été transmises par la tradition orale. La religion hellénique est polythéiste, avec d'innombrables divinités locales de la nature en plus des principaux dieux du panthéon olympien. Les dieux grecs ont forme humaine mais possèdent des pouvoirs surnaturels, ont été engendrés par d'autres dieux mais ne vieillissent pas, ils sont immortels, peuvent voyager sur de très grandes distances instantanément, parler à travers les humains (parfois sans même que ceux-ci s'en aperçoivent), etc. Certains dieux sont les personnifications des forces de la nature (Hélios étant littéralement le dieu du soleil) alors que d'autres ont des personnalités complexes et sont associés à de multiples fonctions (Apollon en étant le meilleur exemple). [PARAGRAPH:1]Dieux et déesses sont tous parents d'une même grande famille, mais il existe des générations distinctes de dieux, et leurs interactions sont parfois très violentes. Le fait est que les dieux olympiens n'occupent leur position dominante qu'après avoir chassé une première génération de dieux appelés les Titans. Cela reflète sans doute le chevauchement culturel mythologique existant entre les Grecs et la civilisation précédente, chassée à leur arrivée dans le Péloponnèse aux alentours de 1000 av. J.-C.. [PARAGRAPH:1]Outre de nombreuses légendes sur les dieux, la tradition orale hellénique est riche de grandes sagas relatant les hauts faits de héros humains, dont un certain nombre ont une ascendance divine. On pense notamment aux légendes d'Héraclès, de Persée, de Jason et des personnages de l'Iliade. Ces mortels entrent souvent en conflit avec des dieux et en triomphent parfois. Nombre d'entre eux, surtout s'ils sont nobles et puissants comme Achille, sont tenus en haute estime par les Grecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] Même si certains des Grecs éduqués entretiennent quelques doutes à propos de la réalité dessinée par la religion hellénique, la grande majorité de la population accepte sans réserve la mythologie comme seule vérité. Les Grecs s'appuient sur leur religion pour expliquer les phénomènes naturels et leurs propres origines, et c'est une source de grande fierté que de pouvoir associer une lignée ou la fondation d'une cité aux actions d'un dieu.[PARAGRAPH:1] Les résultats des recherches archéologiques et linguistiques laissent penser que la religion hellénique a été très influencée par d'autres religions. C'est ainsi que le dieu grec Zeus, le dieu romain Jupiter, le dieu germain Tyr et le dieu sanskrit Dyaus sont tous des dieux du ciel, et il est probable qu'ils partagent tous une même lointaine origine indo-européenne. Les Grecs empruntent librement des dieux à d'autres cultes du Proche-Orient, c'est ainsi qu'Aphrodite a des fonctions très proches de celles des déesses sémites Ishtar et Astarté. Au cours de l'époque hellénique et par la suite, la religion grecque se répand à travers la plus grande partie de la Méditerranée et du Proche-Orient, influençant nombre des cultes déjà existants et donnant naissance à de nouveaux cultes syncrétistes. Bien que la religion grecque ne soit plus pratiquée de nos jours, ses mythologies continuent d'enflammer les imaginations et d'illuminer les esprits.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die hellenistische Religion der Antike, auch als griechische Mythologie bezeichnet, umfasste einen enormen Fundus an Götter- und Heldensagen. Diese Geschichten datieren viele Jahrhunderte zurück und blieben in der präliterarischen Zeit durch mündliche Überlieferung erhalten. Der hellenistische Glaube war angesichts der vielen Götter und Göttinnen des Olymps sowie zahlloser regionaler Naturgottheiten extrem polytheistisch geprägt. Die griechischen Götter wurden in der Regel in menschlicher Form dargestellt, besaßen allerdings übernatürliche Kräfte. Sie wurden von anderen Gottheiten geboren, alterten nicht, waren unsterblich, konnten im Nu enorme Entfernungen überwinden, sprachen durch die Menschen (mit oder ohne deren Wissen) etc. Einige Götter verkörperten Naturgewalten (zum Beispiel war Helios im wörtlichen Sinne der Gott der Sonne), während andere komplexe Persönlichkeitsstrukturen aufwiesen und zahlreiche Funktionen wahrnahmen (zum Beispiel Apollon). [PARAGRAPH:1]Als Teil einer großen Familie waren die Götter und Göttinnen alle irgendwie miteinander verwandt, aber es gab eine klare Generationeneinteilung und manchmal bekämpften sie sich auch gegenseitig. Zum Beispiel sollen die Götter des Olymps ihre Vorherrschaft durch den Sturz der vorangehenden Göttergeneration, der so genannten Titanen, gesichert haben. Hierbei könnte es sich um eine mythische Darstellung der kulturellen Überschneidung zwischen den Griechen und der früheren Population in dieser Region handeln, die sie bei der Ankunft auf dem Peleponnes um 1000 vor Christus vertrieben hatten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Neben den vielen Göttergeschichten wurde die griechische Religion auch von zahlreichen grandiosen Sagen über die Abenteuer verschiedener Helden beeinflusst, von denen viele zumindest ein göttliches Elternteil besaßen. Die Erzählungen handelten von heldenhaften Persönlichkeiten wie Herakles, Perseus, Jason sowie den Charakteren der Ilias und inspirierten viele griechische Künstler späterer Generationen. Diese Helden in Menschengestalt kamen häufig mit den Göttern in Kontakt, übertrumpften sie bisweilen sogar und wurden von den Griechen meist hoch geschätzt, insbesondere so ehrenhafte Persönlichkeiten wie zum Beispiel Achilles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Einige der griechischen Gelehrten hatten durchaus Zweifel an dem Wahrheitsgehalt der griechischen Mythologie, dennoch stellte der überwiegende Teil der Bevölkerung die Stichhaltigkeit der überlieferten Legenden nicht in Frage. Die Griechen nutzten ihre Religion, um natürliche Vorgänge und auch ihren eigenen Ursprung zu erklären. Man war stolz darauf, wenn man seine eigene Herkunft oder die Gründung seiner Heimatstadt auf das Einwirken eines Gottes zurückführen konnte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Archäologische und sprachliche Untersuchungen haben ergeben, dass die griechische Religion stark von anderen Religionen beeinflusst war. Zum Beispiel stellen der griechische Gott Zeus, der römische Gott Jupiter, der germanische Gott Tyr und der Sanskrit-Gott Dyaus allesamt Himmelsgötter dar, die irgendwann in der fernen Vergangenheit einen gemeinsamen indo-europäischen Ursprung hatten. Andere Götter wurden von den Religionen im Nahen Osten "ausgeborgt" oder zumindest beeinflusst: Aphrodite besaß frappierend ähnliche Eigenschaften und Funktionen wie die semitischen Göttinnen Ishtar und Astarte. Während der hellenischen Periode und auch danach kam es zu einer starken Verbreitung der griechischen Mythologie über große Teile des Mittelmeerraums und des Nahen Ostens. Sie beeinflusste viele der bereits existierenden Religionen und ebnete den Weg für die Entstehung neuer synkretistischer Mysterienkulte. Obwohl die griechische Religion des hellenistischen Zeitalters heute nicht mehr in dieser Form praktiziert wird, lassen sich auch heute noch Künstler in aller Welt von ihr inspirieren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La religione ellenica, nota anche come "mitologia greca", è composta da un'enorme serie di storie di dei, dee ed eroi, tramandate a lungo tempo oralmente nell'era pre-letteraria. La religione ellenica era politeistica e oltre agli dei e alle dee dell'Olimpo comprendeva innumerevoli divinità naturali locali. Le divinità greche avevano aspetto umano ma erano dotate di poteri soprannaturali; pur nascendo (da altre divinità) non invecchiavano ed erano immortali, potevano coprire enormi distanze istantaneamente, parlare attraverso gli uomini con o senza la loro consapevolezza, ecc. Alcune divinità erano la personificazione di forze naturali (per esempio, Elio era letteralmente il dio del sole), mentre altre avevano personalità complesse e numerose funzioni (Apollo ne è forse il miglior esempio). [PARAGRAPH:1]Le divinità avevano fra loro vincoli di parentela e formavano una grande famiglia, ma potevano distinguersi diverse generazioni, le cui interazioni con le altre avevano spesso esiti violenti. Per fare un esempio, gli dei olimpici avevano raggiunto la loro posizione di dominio estromettendo la precedente generazione dei Titani. Questo fenomeno potrebbe essere un riflesso culturale di ciò che avvenne quando i Greci si sostituirono alla popolazione locale quando giunsero nel Peloponneso intorno al 1000 a.C. [PARAGRAPH:1]Oltre alle storie sugli dei, la mitologia greca è piena di grandi saghe che narrano le gesta di eroi, molti dei quali avevano genitori divini. I miti di Ercole, Perseo, Giasone e le storie dei protagonisti dell'Iliade furono spesso oggetto di rielaborazione da parte degli artisti greci successivi. Si trattava di uomini che interagivano spesso con gli dei, a volte superandoli. Molti di loro erano enormemente stimati dai Greci, soprattutto se "nobili" come Achille. [PARAGRAPH:1]Anche se i Greci meglio istruiti avevano i loro dubbi sul fondamento della religione ellenica, il popolo non metteva in dubbio la veridicità delle storie. I Greci usarono la loro religione per spiegare i fenomeni naturali e le proprie origini; era fonte di orgoglio il fatto che la propria ascendenza o la fondazione della propria città potessero essere fatte risalire a un atto divino. [PARAGRAPH:1]Le analisi archeologiche e linguistiche suggeriscono che la religione ellenica abbia subito una pesante influenza da parte di altre religioni. Per esempio, il dio greco Zeus, il dio romano Giove, il dio germanico Tyr e il dio sanscrito Dyaus sono tutte divinità del cielo che condividono un'origine indo-europea risalente a chissà quando nel passato. Altre divinità furono prese in prestito o influenzate dalle religioni del Vicinio Oriente: Afrodite aveva una funzione simile a quella delle semitiche Ishtar e Astarte. Nel corso del periodo ellenico e anche dopo, la religione greca si diffuse nel Mediterraneo e nel Vicino Oriente, influenzando a sua volta molte religioni pre-esistenti e facendo nascere nuovi culti mistici sincretici. Anche se oggi si tratta di una religione morta, la mitologia greca ha ispirato gli artisti per migliaia di anni.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La religión helénica, también conocida como mitología griega, comprende un cuerpo enorme de narraciones sobre los dioses y héroes. Estas historias tenían muchos siglos de antigüedad y, hasta la aparición de la escritura en Grecia, se conservaron mediante la tradición oral. De naturaleza politeísta, contaba con un sinfín de deidades naturales locales, además de los principales dioses y diosas del Olimpo. Los dioses griegos tenían forma humana, pero poseían poderes sobrenaturales; eran engendrados por otros dioses, pero nunca envejecían, no podían morir, podían cruzar enormes distancias al instante, hablaban a través de los humanos con o sin su consentimiento, etc. Algunos de ellos eran los aspectos personificados de las fuerzas de la naturaleza (Helios, por ejemplo, era literalmente el dios del sol) mientras que otros poseían personalidades complejas y funciones múltiples (seguramente Apolo sea el mejor ejemplo). [PARAGRAPH:1]Todos los dioses pertenecían a una gran familia, pero había varias generaciones diferenciadas y su interacción era en muchas ocasiones violenta. Los dioses del Olimpo, por ejemplo, habían alcanzado su posición de predominio tras expulsar a una generación anterior de dioses y diosas (los titanes). Esto bien pudiera ser una transposición mitológica de la lucha entre los griegos y la cultura anterior, a la que desplazaron cuando llegaron al Peloponeso, alrededor del 1000 a. C. [PARAGRAPH:1]Además de las historias de los dioses, la religión helénica estaba repleta de grandes historias sobre las hazañas de los héroes, muchos de los cuales estaban emparentados con los dioses. Abundan las narraciones acerca de figuras como Hércules, Perseo, Jasón y los personajes de la Ilíada. Estos humanos solían relacionarse con los dioses y, a veces, hasta los superaban. Los griegos sentían gran estima por estos héroes, especialmente por los personajes "nobles", como por ejemplo Aquiles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Aunque algunos griegos cultivados tenían sus dudas sobre la existencia de los dioses, la mayoría no cuestionaba la validez de las historias. Los griegos utilizaban su religión para explicar el mundo natural y sus propios orígenes. Desde trazar los orígenes del propio linaje o la fundación de una ciudad hasta los actos de un dios era motivo de gran orgullo. [PARAGRAPH:1]La arqueología y el análisis lingüístico sugieren que la religión helénica estuvo muy influida por otras religiones. Por poner un ejemplo, el Zeus griego, el Júpiter romano, el Tyr germano y el Dyaus sánscrito son todos dioses del cielo que comparten un origen indoeuropeo común en un pasado lejano. Otros dioses procedían de religiones de Oriente Próximo (o habían recibido importantes influencias de ellas): Afrodita poseía una función muy similar a la de las diosas semíticas Ishtar y Astarté. Durante el período helenístico y después de él, la religión griega se extendió por gran parte del Mediterráneo y Oriente Próximo, lo que influyó en muchas de las religiones existentes y originó nuevos cultos mistéricos y sincréticos. Aunque la religión helénica ya no cuenta con seguidores, sigue siendo una gran fuente de inspiración para artistas del mundo entero.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Temple

[TAB]In Civilization IV, a temple is defined as a building where the faithful come to worship. Christians call their temples "churches," while Muslims call theirs "mosques," and Jews call theirs, simply, "temples." Temples are far more common than cathedrals, but much less large and ornate. Even the smallest village can possess a temple.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans Civilization IV, un petit lieu de culte est défini comme un édifice dans lequel les fidèles viennent pratiquer leur religion : "églises" pour les chrétiens, "petites mosquées" pour les musulmans et "petites synagogues" pour les juifs. Ces petits lieux de culte sont bien plus courants que les grands lieux de culte mais sont de taille plus réduite et sont bien moins richement ornés. Même le village le plus petit peut posséder un petit lieu de culte.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In Civilization IV sind Tempel Gebäude, in denen Gläubige beten. Christen nennen ihre Tempel "Kirchen", Moslems "Moscheen". Es gibt deutlich mehr Tempel als Kathedralen. Allerdings sind sie wesentlich kleiner und schlichter. Selbst das kleinste Dorf kann einen Tempel besitzen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In Civilization IV, il tempio è un edificio all'interno del quale i fedeli si recano a pregare. I Cristiani chiamano i loro templi "chiese", i Musulmani "moschee", gli Ebrei semplicemente "templi". I templi sono più comuni delle cattedrali, ma sono più piccoli e poco fastosi. Anche il villaggio più piccolo ospita un tempio.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]En Civilization IV, un templo se define como un lugar al que los fieles acuden a venerar. Los cristianos llaman a sus templos "iglesias", mientras que para los musulmanes son "mezquitas" y para los judíos, sencillamente, "templos". Son mucho más comunes que las catedrales, pero también mucho más pequeños y humildes. Hasta la más pequeña aldea puede poseer uno.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Cathedral (Pantheon)

[TAB]In Civilization IV, a cathedral is defined as an especially large and ornate religious building where the faithful worship. Only the most prosperous cities can afford to create cathedrals, as they require huge amounts of raw material and years of dedicated labor by skilled craftsmen. For example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France, took over two centuries to complete.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans Civilization IV, un grand lieu de culte est défini comme un édifice religieux particulièrement grand et richement orné dans lequel les fidèles pratiquent leur religion : "cathédrales" pour les chrétiens, "mosquées" pour les musulmans et "synagogues" pour les juifs. Seules les villes les plus prospères ont les moyens de construire de tels édifices. En effet, ils nécessitent d'énormes quantités de matériaux bruts et des artisans spécialisés doivent y consacrer des années de travail. Ainsi, il a fallu plus de deux siècles pour terminer la cathédrale Notre-Dame à Paris.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In Civilization IV sind Kathedralen große und prächtige Gotteshäuser, in denen Gläubige beten. Nur die reichsten aller Städte können sich den Bau einer Kathedrale leisten, da hierfür große Mengen an Baumaterial und die jahrelange Arbeit erfahrener Handwerker erforderlich sind. Die Kathedrale von Notre Dame in Paris wurde beispielsweise erst nach 200-jähriger Bauzeit fertig gestellt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In Civilization IV, viene definito cattedrale un edificio religioso particolarmente grande e sfarzoso adibito a luogo di culto per i fedeli. Solamente le città più prosperose possono permettersi l'edificazione di cattedrali poiché sono necessari un'enorme quantità di materiali e operai esperti. Per esempio, per completare la cattedrale di Notre-Dame de Paris, in Francia, ci sono voluti più di due secoli.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]En Civilization IV, una catedral se define como un edificio religioso especialmente grande y ornamentado en el que se reúnen los fieles para celebrar sus ritos. Solo las ciudades más grandes pueden permitirse el lujo de crear catedrales, puesto que requieren enormes cantidades de materias primas y años de dedicación por parte de trabajadores especializados. Por ejemplo, la catedral de Notre Dame, Francia, tardó dos siglos en completarse.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Monastry (Gymnasia)

[TAB]A monastery is a building where monks can retreat from the world and concentrate upon the divine. Usually a monastery will have strict rules of conduct to protect its unworldly members from temptation. In some monasteries, the monks are totally silent; in others no visitors are allowed inside. Monasteries usually have many daily rituals and religious services. [PARAGRAPH:1] Throughout the ages monasteries have often been centers of learning. In remote areas the monks may be the only literate people for miles around. Monks have often been employed as scribes, copying out the words of their religion's sacred scripture. Monasteries frequently have extensive libraries, holding religious, scientific, medical and philosophical texts.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un monastère est un édifice dans lequel les moines peuvent se retirer du monde et se concentrer sur le divin. Généralement, les règles de conduite y sont strictes afin de protéger ses membres, détachés du monde, de la tentation. Dans certains monastères, les moines sont totalement silencieux ; dans d'autres, les visiteurs ne sont pas autorisés à pénétrer dans leur enceinte. Les monastères ont généralement de nombreux rituels et services religieux quotidiens. [PARAGRAPH:1]A travers les siècles, les monastères ont souvent été des centres d'érudition. Dans les zones retirées, les moines étaient parfois les seules personnes sachant lire et écrire à des kilomètres à la ronde. Ils ont souvent servi de scribes, recopiant les textes sacrés de leur religion. Les monastères ont généralement de grandes bibliothèques possédant des textes religieux, scientifiques, médicaux et philosophiques.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Klöster sind Gebäude, in die sich Mönche zurückziehen, um sich auf Gott zu konzentrieren. In Klöstern gelten strenge Verhaltensregeln, die die Mönche vor Versuchungen bewahren sollen. In einigen Klöstern herrscht ein strenges Redeverbot, in anderen sind keine Besucher gestattet. Die Mönche selbst gehen täglich ihren religiösen Pflichten nach. [PARAGRAPH:1] In der Vergangenheit waren Klöster stets auch Zentren des Wissens. In abgelegenen Gegenden waren die Mönche oft die einzigen gebildeten Menschen, die als Schreiber ihre religiösen Schriften kopierten. Klöster haben nicht selten Bibliotheken, in denen unzählige religiöse, wissenschaftliche, medizinische und philosophische Texte aufbewahrt werden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il monastero è un edificio nel quale i monaci possono ritirarsi dal mondo e concentrarsi sul Divino. In genere, nel monastero vige un regolamento ferreo per proteggere i membri della comunità dalle tentazioni. In alcuni monasteri, i monaci erano completamente silenziosi e non erano permesse visite dall'esterno per non interrompere i rituali quotidiani e le cerimonie religiose. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nel corso dei secoli, i monasteri sono stati spesso centro di insegnamento: in alcune zone, i monaci erano sovente gli unici in grado di leggere e scrivere nel giro di diversi chilometri. Da sempre, i monaci sono stati utilizzati come scribi per copiare le parole sacre della propria religione; i monasteri ospitavano spesso delle biblioteche che contenevano testi religiosi, scientifici, medici e filosofici.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un monasterio es un edificio en el que los monjes pueden retirarse del mundo para concentrarse en los asuntos de la divinidad. Normalmente tienen estrictas reglas de comportamiento para proteger a sus miembros de la tentación. En algunos monasterios, los monjes guardan un silencio total, mientras que en otros no se permite el acceso a los visitantes. Lo habitual es que sus miembros tengan que celebrar a diario muchos rituales y servicios religiosos. [PARAGRAPH:1] A lo largo de la historia, los monasterios han sido muchas veces centros de estudio. En las regiones remotas, los monjes podían ser las únicas personas letradas en muchos kilómetros a la redonda. A menudo han sido empleados como escribas, y se han dedicado a copiar los textos sagrados de su religión. Normalmente cuentan con grandes bibliotecas, que contienen textos religiosos, científicos, médicos y filosóficos.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Shrine (The Statue of Zeus)

[TAB]Many monuments were created to honor Zeus, King of the Greek Gods, yet none could be as impressive as the Statue of Zeus at Olympia. Over forty feet tall, the Statue filled the temple in which it was constructed from floor to ceiling. Created by the master artisan Phidias between 438 and 446BC, the whole statue rested on a wooden frame built upon a cedarwood throne of appropriate size for a forty-foot deity. The frame was then draped in ivory and gold (ivory for skin, gold for clothing) and covered from head to toe in jewels. Before Zeus' feet, a shallow lake of olive oil reflected light into the temple, illuminating the otherwise closed building. Every four years, when the Olympic Games would be held in the town, Olympic competitors would approach the statue and make sacrifices to the King of the Gods with the hope of assuring their victory.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Beaucoup de monuments ont été érigés pour honorer Zeus, roi des dieux grecs. Cependant, aucun ne saurait être aussi impressionnant que la statue de Zeus à Olympie. Mesurant plus de 12 mètres de haut, la statue atteignait le plafond du temple dans lequel elle a été construite. Créée par le maître artisan Phidias entre 438 et 446 av. J.C., la statue repose sur un cadre en bois construit sur un énorme trône en cèdre. Le cadre a ensuite été drapé d'or et d'ivoire (ivoire pour la peau, or pour les vêtements) et couvert de bijoux. Aux pieds de Zeus, un lac d'huile d'olive réfléchissait la lumière, illuminant le temple. Tous les quatre ans, lorsque les jeux olympiques avaient lieu en ville, les concurrents s'approchaient de la statue et faisaient des sacrifices au roi des dieux dans l'espoir qu'il leur assurerait la victoire.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Viele Monumente wurden zu Ehren des griechischen Götterkönigs Zeus erschaffen, aber keins war so beeindruckend wie die Zeus-Statue von Olympia. Mit über zwölf Metern füllte die Statue die gesamte Raumhöhe des Tempels, in dem sie errichtet wurde. Sie wurde zwischen 446 und 438 v. Chr. vom Meistersteinmetz Phidias erschaffen und stützte sich auf ein hölzernes Gerüst, das auf einem in seinen Dimensionen der zwölf Meter hohen Gottheit angemessenen Thron aus Zedernholz fußte. Das Gerüst wurde mit Elfenbein und Gold verziert (Elfenbein für die Haut, Gold für das Gewand) und von Kopf bis Fuß mit Juwelen behangen. Vor Zeus' Füßen reflektierte ein seichter See aus Olivenöl das Licht in das Innere des Tempels und erhellte das ansonsten geschlossene Gebäude. Alle vier Jahre, während die Olympischen Spiele in der Stadt ausgetragen wurden, näherten sich die Wettkämpfer der Statue und brachten dem König der Götter Opfer dar, in der Hoffnung, er möge ihnen dafür den Sieg schenken.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Furono eretti molti monumenti per onorare Zeus, il signore degli dei greci, ma nessuno è da considerarsi tanto maestoso quanto la Statua di Zeus a Olimpia. La Statua era alta più di 12 metri, raggiungendo il soffitto del tempio in cui era stata costruita. Creata dal maestro artigiano Fidia tra il 438 e il 446 a.C., l'intera statua era composta da una struttura di legno costruita su un trono di cedro di dimensioni appropriate per una divinità alta 12 metri. La struttura era poi coperta di oro e avorio (avorio per la pelle, oro per i vestiti) e coperta dalla testa ai piedi di gioielli. Davanti ai piedi di Zeus un lago poco profondo di olio d'oliva rifletteva la luce nel tempio, illuminando l'edificio altrimenti chiuso. Ogni quattro anni, quando si tenevano in città i Giochi Olimpici, i concorrenti si avvicinavano alla statua per fare sacrifici al Re degli Dei, nella speranza che concedesse loro la vittoria.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Hubo muchos monumentos consagrados a Zeus, rey de los dioses griegos, pero ninguno de ellos tan impresionante como la estatua de Olimpia. Con sus casi quince metros de altura, la estatua llenaba el templo en el que estaba construido desde el suelo hasta el techo. Creada por el maestro Fidias entre los años 438 y 446 a. C., la estatua descansaba sobre una estructura de madera construida encima de un trono de cedro del tamaño apropiado para una escultura de semejantes dimensiones. La estructura estaba luego revestida de marfil y oro (marfil para la piel, oro para la ropa) y cubierta de joyas de la cabeza a los pies. A los pies de Zeus, un estanque poco profundo de aceite de oliva reflejaba la luz hacia el interior del templo, que no contaba con otros medios de iluminación. Cada cuatro años, cuando se celebraban los Juegos Olímpicos en el la ciudad, los competidores se acercaban al rey de los dioses y depositaban sus ofrendas a sus pies con la esperanza de que les concediera la victoria.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Wonder (The Parthenon)

[TAB]The Parthenon was constructed in 433 BC, in Athens, Greece, in honor of Athens' patron goddess, Athena. Measuring 100 feet by 225 feet, the Parthenon is constructed almost totally of marble. The exterior of the Parthenon is ringed with Doric-style columns more than 30 feet in height, and the center part of the temple, called the "cella," is a large open space which once held a statue of Athena. Much of the temple was decorated with beautiful marble statues and friezes celebrating Athena and the glories of Athens. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Parthenon has suffered much from the ravages of time. In the 5th century a Roman Emperor stole the statue of Athena and moved it to Constantinople, where it was subsequently destroyed. In the 13th century the Parthenon was converted to a Catholic church, which involved altering the internal structure and removing (and probably destroying) many statues dedicated to the old gods. In the 15th century Athens was captured by the Ottomans, and the temple was turned into a mosque. In the 17th century the Parthenon was partially destroyed during a war between the Ottomans and Venetians. Finally, in the 19th century, the British ambassador to Greece looted all of the surviving marble friezes from the building, which he subsequently sold to the British museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]Despite the centuries of neglect, mutilation and pillaging, the Parthenon still stands - a remarkably powerful and beautiful symbol of the glories of ancient Greece.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le Parthénon a été construit en 433 av. J.-C. à Athènes, en Grèce, en l'honneur de la déesse Athéna, patronne d'Athènes. Mesurant 70 m sur 31 m, le Parthénon est construit pratiquement entièrement en marbre. A l'extérieur, il est entouré de colonnes doriques mesurant plus de 9 m de haut et au centre du temple, appelé "naos", se trouve un vaste espace abritant une statue d'Athéna. Une grande partie du temple était décorée de magnifiques statues de marbre et de frises célébrant Athéna et les gloires d'Athènes. [PARAGRAPH:2]Le Parthénon a beaucoup souffert des ravages du temps. Au Ve siècle, un empereur romain vola la statue d'Athéna et la transporta à Constantinople, où elle fut détruite. Au XIIIe siècle, le Parthénon fut transformé en une église catholique, ce qui entraîna une modification de la structure interne ainsi que la suppression (et sans doute aussi la destruction) de nombreuses statues consacrées aux anciens dieux. Au XVe siècle, Athènes fut prise par les Ottomans et le temple se trouva transformé en mosquée. Au XVIIe siècle, le Parthénon fut partiellement détruit lors d'une guerre entre les Ottomans et les Vénitiens. Enfin, au XIXe siècle, l'ambassadeur britannique en Grèce pilla toutes les fresques de marbre subsistantes, dans le bâtiment, pour les vendre au British Museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]En dépit des siècles de négligences, de mutilations et de pillages, le Parthénon subsiste, symbole magnifique et remarquablement fort des gloires de la Grèce antique.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Parthenon wurde 433 vor Christus in Athen zu Ehren der Göttin Athene gebaut. Die Säulen des etwa 30 mal 70 Meter großen, im dorischen Stil erbauten Tempels sind über 8 Meter hoch. Der zentrale Teil des Tempels (Cella) ist eine große Fläche, auf der einst eine Athene-Statue stand. Ein Großteil des Tempels war mit Marmorstatuen und -fresken verziert, die Athene und den Ruhm Athens symbolisierten. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Parthenon hat im Laufe der Jahrhunderte sehr gelitten. Im 5. Jahrhundert stahl ein römischer Kaiser die Statue der Athene und brachte sie nach Konstantinopel, wo sie schließlich zerstört wurde. Im 13. Jahrhundert wurde der Parthenon als katholische Kirche geweiht. Dabei wurden die inneren Strukturen verändert und viele heidnische Götterstatuen zerstört. Im 15. Jahrhundert besetzten die Ottomanen Athen und nutzten den Parthenon als Moschee. Im 17. Jahrhundert wurde der Parthenon teilweise zerstört. Schließlich raubte der britische Botschafter in Griechenland die noch erhaltenen Marmorfresken und verkaufte diese an das British Museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]Trotz der Vernachlässigung, Zerstörung und Plünderung steht der Parthenon noch immer ... als mächtiges Symbol der Blütezeit Griechenlands.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il Partenone fu costruito ad Atene, in Grecia, intorno al 433 a. C. in favore di Atena. Alto circa 30 metri e lungo 70, il Partenone è completamente realizzato in marmo. L'esterno del Partenone è ricco di colonne doriche alte più di 10 metri e la parte centrale del tempio, chiamata la "cella", è un grande spazio aperto dove una volta di trovava una statua di Atena. Buona parte del tempio è decorato con meravigliose statue di marmo e fregi che celebrano Atena e la gloria di Atene. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il Partenone è stato danneggiato con il passare del tempo: nel V secolo, un Imperatore Romano rubò la statua di Atena e la spostò a Costantinopoli dove venne successivamente distrutta. Nel XIII secolo il Partenone fu convertito a chiesa Cattolica: per questo motivo vennero apportate molte modifiche alla struttura e vennero rimosse (probabilmente distrutte) molte delle statue dedicate alle antiche divinità. Nel XV secolo, Atene venne conquistata dagli Ottomani e il tempio venne adibito a moschea: nel XVII secolo, il Partenone fu distrutto parzialmente dalla guerra tra Ottomani e Veneziani. Infine, nel XIX secolo, l'ambasciatore Britannico in Grecia saccheggiò tutti i rimanenti fregi di marmo dall'edificio, che vennero successivamente venduti al British Museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]Malgrado secoli di trascuratezza, mutilazioni, saccheggi, il Partenone è ancora al suo posto, un simbolo che ricorda la potenza e la bellezza dell'antica Grecia.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El Partenón se construyó en el 433 a. C., en Atenas, Grecia, en honor a la diosa patrona de esta ciudad, Atenea. Mide unos 70 x 30 metros y está construido casi totalmente de mármol. El exterior está rodeado por un peristilo de estilo dórico de más de diez metros de altura y la parte central del templo, llamada "cella", es un espacio abierto en el que antaño se levantó la estatua de Atenea. Gran parte del templo estaba decorada con preciosos frisos y estatuas de mármol en honor de Atenea y las glorias de Atenas. [PARAGRAPH:2]El Partenón ha sufrido muchos pillajes con el paso del tiempo. En el s. V, un emperador romano robó la estatua de Atenea y se la llevó a Constantinopla, donde posteriormente fue destruida. En el s. XIII se convirtió en una iglesia católica, lo que supuso alterar su estructura interna y quitar (y probablemente destruir) muchas estatuas dedicadas a los antiguos dioses. En el s. XV, Atenas fue capturada por los otomanos, y el templo se convirtió en una mezquita. En el s. XVII fue parcialmente destruido durante una guerra entre otomanos y venecianos. Finalmente, en el s. XIX, el embajador británico en Grecia saqueó todos los frisos de mármol que quedaban y posteriormente se los vendió al British Museum. [PARAGRAPH:2]Pese a siglos de abandono, mutilación y pillaje, el Partenón aún se alza como un símbolo excepcionalmente poderoso y bello de las glorias de la antigua Grecia.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Wonder (The Erechtheum)

[TAB]The Erechtheum is an ancient Greek temple on the north side of the Acropolis of Athens in Greece.The Erectheum was associated with some of the most ancient and holy relics of the Athenians: the Palladion, which was a xoanon (defined as a wooden effigy fallen from heaven - not man-made) of Athena Polias (Protectress of the City); the marks of Poseidon's trident and the salt water well (the "salt sea") that resulted from Poseidon's strike; the sacred olive tree that sprouted when Athena struck the rock with her spear in her successful rivalry with Poseidon for the city; the supposed burial places of the mythical kings Cecrops and Erechtheus; the sacred precincts of Cecrops' three daughters, Herse, Pandrosus and Aglaurus; and those of the tribal heroes Pandion and Boutes.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'Eretteo è un antico tempio greco sul lato nord dell'Acropoli di Atene, in Grecia. L'Eretteo è stato associato con alcuni dei reperti più antichi e santi degli Ateniesi: il Palladio, che era un xoanon (definita come una effigie di legno caduta dal cielo - non umana) di Atena Polia (protettrice della città); i segni del tridente di Poseidone e il pozzo di acqua salata (il "mare di sale"), il risultato del colpo di Poseidone; l'olivo sacro che spuntò quando Atena colpì la roccia con la sua lancia nella sua rivalità con Poseidone per la città; il presunto luogo di sepoltura del mitico re Cecrope ed Eretteo; i recinti sacri delle tre figlie di Cecrope, ovveri Erse, Pandrosus e Aglauro; e quelli degli eroi tribali Pandion e Boutes.

TEXT.English: Build the Erechtheum to give a bonus to naval units built in this city.
TEXT.Italian: Costruisci l'Eretteo per fornire un bonus alle unità navali addestrate in questa città.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Wonder (Phidias Statue Workshop)

[TAB]Phidias was a Greek sculptor, painter and architect, who lived in the 5th century BC, and is commonly regarded as one of the greatest of all sculptors of Classical Greece: Phidias' Statue of Zeus at Olympia was one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Phidias also designed the statues of the goddess Athena on the Athenian Acropolis, namely the Athena Parthenos inside the Parthenon and the Athena Promachos, a colossal bronze statue of Athena which stood between it and the the Propylaea, a monumental gateway that served as the entrance to the Acropolis in Athens. Phidias was the son of a certain Charmides.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Fidia è stato uno scultore, pittore e architetto greco, vissuto nel 5° secolo a.C.; è comunemente considerato uno dei più grandi di tutti gli scultori della Grecia classica: la Statua di Zeus realizzata da Fidia a Olimpia era una delle sette meraviglie del Mondo Antico. Fidia progettò anche le statue della dea Atena sull'Acropoli ateniese, ovvero l'Athena Parthenos dentro il Partenone e l'Athena Promachos, una colossale statua di bronzo di Atena che sorgeva tra di esso e i Propilei, l'ingresso monumentale che faceva da entrata all'Acropoli di Atene. Fidia era figlio di un certo Carmide.

TEXT.English: Build the Phidias workshop to get a boost to culture in all your cities.
TEXT.Italian: Costruisci l'atelier di Fidia per ottenere un bonus alla cultura in tutte le tue città.

TEXT.English: Hellenic Wonder (The Necromanteion)

[TAB]The Nekromanteion is the ancient Greek temple of necromancy devoted to Hades and Persephone. It is situated on an archaeological site located in northwestern Greece (Ephyra) overlooking the Acheron river. This site was believed by devotees to be the door to Hades, the realm of the dead. The word Nekromanteion means "Oracle of Death", and the faithful came here to talk with their late ancestors.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il Nekromanteion è l'antico tempio greco della negromanzia, dedicato a Ade e Persefone. Si trova su un sito archeologico situato nella Grecia nord-occidentale (Efira) con vista sul fiume Acheronte. Secondo i fedeli, questo sito era la porta dell'Ade, il regno dei morti. La parola Nekromanteion significa "Oracolo della Morte", e i fedeli venivano qui per parlare con loro agli antenati.

TEXT.English: Build the Necromanteion to get a bonus from all your priests.
TEXT.Italian: Costruisci il Necromanteion per fornire bonus a tutti i tuoi sacerdoti.

TEXT.English: Hindu Cathedral (Mandir)
Hindu Shrine (The Kashi Vishwanath)
Hindu Wonder (Akshardham)

[TAB]Akshardham is a Hindu temple complex in Delhi, India. The complex displays centuries of traditional Indian and Hindu culture, spirituality, and architecture. The building was inspired and moderated by Pramukh Swami Maharaj, the spiritual head of the Bochasanwasi Shri Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha, whose 3,000 volunteers helped 7,000 artisans construct Akshardham. The temple, which attracts approximately 70 percent of all tourists who visit Delhi, was officially opened on 6 November 2005. It sits on the banks of the Yamuna adjacent to the proposed 2010 Commonwealth Games village. The monument at the center of the complex of built off of the Vastu Shastra and Pancharatra Shastra. The complex features a large central monument crafted entirely of stone, exhibitions on incidents from the life of Bhagwan Swaminarayan and the history of India, an IMAX feature, a musical fountain, and large landscaped gardens.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Akshardham è un complesso di templi indù a Delhi, in India. Il complesso presenta secoli di tradizione indiana e cultura, spiritualità e architettura indù. L'edificio è stato ispirato e moderato da Pramukh Swami Maharaj, il capo spirituale della Bochasanwasi Shri Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha, i cui 3.000 volontari hanno aiutato 7.000 artigiani a costruire l'Akshardham. Il tempio, che attira circa il 70 per cento di tutti i turisti che visitano Delhi, è stato ufficialmente inaugurato il 6 novembre 2005. Si trova sulle rive della Yamuna adiacente al villaggio dei Giochi del Commonwealth del 2010. Il monumento al centro del complesso è costruito fuori del Vastu Shastra e Pancharatra Shastra. Il complesso dispone di un grande monumento centrale realizzato interamente in pietra, scenedi episodi della vita di Bhagwan Swaminarayan e la storia dell'India, una caratteristica IMAX, una fontana musicale e grandi giardini monumentali.

TEXT.English: Akshardam gives your city a bonus to science, a free scientist, to increase the great people rate and to decrease whipping anger.
TEXT.Italian: L'Akshardam fornisce alla tua città un bonus alla ricerca, uno scienziato gratuito, incrementa il ritmo di nascita dei grandi personaggi e diminuisce la lunghezza dell'anarchia.

TEXT.English: Hindu Wonder (The Brihadeeswarar Temple)

[TAB]The Brihadeeswarar temple is an ancient Hindu temple located at Thanjavur in the state of Tamil Nadu, India. The temple is dedicated to Shiva and dates to the Chola dynasty rule in the 11th century CE. The temple is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site "Great Living Chola Temples". This temple is one of India's most prized architectural sites. It depicts the amazing and outstanding efforts of the ancient Indians. The building that carries the main sanctum is known as the 'Periya Kovil'. This stands amidst fortified walls that were probably added in the 16th century. The 'Vimana' of the temple is about 70 meters and is among the tallest of its kind in the world. The 'Shikharam' (crown) of Brihadeswara temple is itself very large and heavy (81.25 tons) and has been carved out of a single stone.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le temple de Brihadisvara — appelé aussi temple de Râjarâjeshvaram, d'après le nom de son constructeur — situé dans la ville de Tanjavûr dans l'État du Tamil Nadu en Inde est une réalisation exemplaire du style drâvidien d'architecture religieuse. Il fut construit par le roi Chola Râjarâja entre 1003 à 1010. Le 257e jour de la 25e année de son règne (1010), Râjarâja assiste à l'installation du pot de cuivre au sommet du vimâna de 13 étages, pour un total de 66 m, couronné d'un bloc monolithique de 80 tonnes. Cette cérémonie indique que la construction du temple est terminée et qu'il est en fonction. Le bâtiment, dédié à Shiva-Rudra, est entouré de deux enceintes rectangulaires, et il est lui-même, fait de blocs de granit. La légende disait qu'une rampe de terre de plus de 6 km avait été nécessaire pour monter le bulbe monolithique jusqu'à son emplacement au sommet du vimâna, une technique utilisée aussi dans l'Égypte antique, des archéologues ont, semble-t-il, découvert des vestiges attestant de cet artifice.

TEXT.English: Hindu Wonder (Meenakshi Temple)

[TAB]Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple is a historic Hindu temple located in the holy city of Madurai. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva (in the form of Sundareswarar or Beautiful Lord) and his consort, Goddess Parvati (in the form of Meenakshi). The temple forms the heart and lifeline of the 2500 year old city of Madurai. This temple has a stunning architecture and a significant testimony for Vishwakarma Brahmins for their master architecture in sculpting this temple. The complex houses 14 magnificent Gopurams or towers including two golden Gopurams for the main deities, that are elaborately sculptured and painted. The temple is a significant symbol for the Tamil people, and has been mentioned since antiquity in Tamil literature, though the present structure is believed to have been built only recently in the early 17th century. This magnificient architectual wonder was a frontrunner in the election for the modern seven wonders of the world for its architectural importance.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il tempio di Sundareswarar Meenakshi è un tempio storico indù situato nella città santa di Madurai. E' dedicato a Shiva (nella forma di Sundareswarar, Signore Magnifico) e alla sua consorte, la dea Parvati (in forma di Meenakshi). Il tempio è il cuore e la linfa vitale della città di Madurai da più di 2500 anni. Questo tempio ha una splendida architettura e una testimonianza significativa per i bramini Vishwakarma, per la loro bravura nelle sculture di questo tempio. Il complesso ospita 14 splendide Gopurams (torri) di cui due Gopurams d'oro per le principali divinità, che sono riccamente scolpite e dipinte. Il tempio è un simbolo significativo per il popolo Tamil, ed è stato citato fin dall'antichità nella letteratura tamil, anche se la struttura attuale si ritiene sia stata costruita solo di recente, nei primi anni del 17° secolo. Questa meraviglia architettonica magnifica era un capofila nelle elezioni per le moderne sette meraviglie del mondo, per la sua importanza architettonica.

TEXT.English: Meenakshi Temple gives your city a free artist, a bonus to culture, increases your great people rate and decreases anarchy length.
TEXT.Italian: Il Tempio Meenakshi fornisce alla tua città un artista gratuito e un bonus alla cultura, incrementa il tasso di nascita dei grandi personaggi e diminuisce la lunghezza dell'anarchia.

Islamic Wonder (Alhambra)
TEXT.Italian: Alhambra

TEXT.English: The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex of the Moorish monarchs of Granada, in southern Spain (known as Al-Andalus when the fortress was constructed), occupying a hilly terrace on the south-eastern border of the city of Granada. It was the residence of the Muslim kings of Granada and their court, but is currently a museum exhibiting exquisite Islamic architecture. A Renaissance palace was also inserted by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.[PARAGRAPH:1]The name Alhambra, signifying in Arabic the red, derives from the colour of the red clay of the surroundings of which the fort is made. The buildings of the Alhambra were originally whitewashed; however, the buildings now seen today are reddish. The first reference to the Qal'at al Hamra was during the battles between the Arabs and the Muladies during the rule of the Abdallah (who reigned from 888-912). In one particularly fierce and bloody skirmish, the Muladies soundly defeated the Arabs who were then forced to take shelter in a primitive red castle located in the province of Elvira, nowadays located in Granada. According to surviving documents from the era, the red castle was quite small and its walls were not capable of deterring army intent on conquering. The castle was then largely ignored until the eleventh century when its ruins were renovated and rebuilt by Samuel ibn Naghralla, vizier to the King Badis of the Zirid Dynasty, in an attempt to preserve the small Jewish settlement also located on the Sabikah hill. However, evidence from Arab texts indicates that the fortress was easily penetrated and that the actual Alhambra that survives today was built during the Nasrid Dynasty. -Wikipedia
Alhambra requires Islam and it grants +1 gold per city with Islam. It acts as government center and reduces maintenance in nearby cities. Increases defense in all cities.
Islamic Wonder (Blue Mosque)

[TAB]The Sultan Ahmed Mosque is the national mosque of Turkey . The mosque is one of several mosques known as the Blue Mosque for the blue tiles adorning the walls of its interior. It was built between 1609 and 1616, during the rule of Ahmed I. Like many other mosques, it also comprises a tomb of the founder, a madrasah and a hospice. The Sultan Ahmed Mosque has become one of the most popular tourist attractions in Istanbul.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La Moschea del Sultano Ahmed è la moschea nazionale della Turchia; fa parte di un complesso di moschee ed è mehlio nota come la Moschea Blu per le piastrelle blu che ornano le pareti del suo interno. E' stata costruita tra il 1609 e il 1616, durante il regno di Ahmed I. Come molte altre moschee che comprende anche una tomba del fondatore, una madrassa e un ospizio. La Moschea del Sultano Ahmed è diventata una delle più popolari attrazioni turistiche di Istanbul.

TEXT.English: Blue mosque gives to your city a free merchant and a bonus to gold.
TEXT.Italian: La Moschea blu fornisce alla tua città un mercante gratuito, oltre a un bonus alla produzione di oro.

TEXT.English: Islamic Wonder (Great Mosque of Djenné)

[TAB]The Great Mosque of Djenné is the largest mud brick or adobe building in the world and is considered by many architects to be the greatest achievement of the Sudano-Sahelian architectural style, albeit with definite Islamic influences. The mosque is located in the city of Djenné, Mali on the flood plain of the Bani River. The first mosque on the site was built in the 13th century, but the current structure dates from 1907. As well as being the centre of the community of Djenné, it is one of the most famous landmarks in Africa. Along with the "Old Towns of Djenné" it was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1988.

[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The Great Mosque of Djenné[COLOR_REVERT] provides +2[ICON_COMMERCE] on desert tiles in the owner city's radius in addition to reducing the cost of cathedrals by 50% in all cities.
Islamic Wonder (Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque)
TEXT.French: La Grande Mosquée du Sultan Qaboos

TEXT.English: [TAB]In 1992 Sultan Qaboos directed that his country of Oman should have a Grand Mosque. A competition for its design took place in 1993 and after a site was chosen at Bausher construction commenced in 1995. Building work, which was undertaken by Carillion Alawi took six years and four months. The Mosque is built from 300,000 tonnes of Indian sandstone. The main musalla (prayer hall) is square (external dimensions 74.4 x 74.4 metres) with a central dome rising to a height of fifty metres above the floor. The dome and the main minaret (90 metres) and four flanking minarets (45.5 metres) are the mosque’s chief visual features. The main musalla can hold over 6,500 worshippers, while the women’s musalla can accommodate 750 worshippers. The outer paved ground can hold 8,000 worshippers and there is additional space available in the interior courtyard and the passageways, making a total capacity of up to 20,000 worshippers.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Nel 1992 il sultano Qaboos decise che il suo paese, l'Oman, doveva avere una grande moschea. Un concorso per il suo design vene indetto nel 1993; dopo che il sito venne scelto a Bausher, la costruzione iniziò nel 1995. I lavori di costruzione, che è stata intrapresa da Carillion Alawi, sono durati sei anni e quattro mesi. La moschea è stata costruita con 300.000 tonnellate di arenaria indiana. Il Musalla principale (sala di preghiera) è quadrato (dimensioni esterne 74,4 x 74,4 metri) con una cupola centrale che sale fino a un'altezza di cinquanta metri dal pavimento. La cupola, il minareto principale (90 metri) e i quattro minareti che li fiancheggiano (45.5 metri) sono le principali caratteristiche visive della moschea. Il Musalla principale può contenere oltre 6.500 fedeli, mentre la sala delle donne può ospitare 750 fedeli. Il terreno lastricato esterno può contenere 8.000 fedeli e vi è ulteriore spazio a disposizione nel cortile interno e nelle zone di passaggio, portando la capacità totale fino a 20.000 fedeli.

TEXT.English: Sultan Qaboos Great Mosque increases your cities culture, adds a free engineer and gives a bonus to trade routes.
TEXT.Italian: La grande moschea del sultano Qaboos incrementa la cultura della tua città, fornisce un ingegnere gratis e migliora la resa delle tue rotte commerciali.
